prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for kicking a guy out of my hobby group because of his concealed gun?
I am in a little board game group that has been meeting regularly for the past six months. We used to have our game nights at a local hobby shop, but since we've gotten closer and the shop is in not the best part of town, have recently decided to start doing it at my house instead.

There's five of us total and one guy, "Jim" has a concealed carry permit and carries a gun with him. I know this because he's mentioned that he's always armed. I am very anti-gun but it had never come up before. Before our first game night at my place I told Jim privately that I don't want any guns in my house and that he would have to leave his in his truck if he brang it. He gave kind of an acknowledging but not exactly affirming response.

Then after our first game session at my house, one of the other group members told me on her way out that Jim had told her he still had his gun with him while I was in the kitchen out of earshot. I texted Jim and told me he had been extremely disrespectful and that this wasn't a game, and he could not come to my house again if he was going to have a gun on him. His response was "Fine, guess I won't be coming then," and he effectively quit the group.

The reaction with the rest of the group is split. One person doesn't care whether Jim participates or not, one person says it was "harsh but fair" and that Jim wasn't really kicked out per se, and one person thinks I am being a shrew and shouldn't have been so uptight about the gun after just one session, since he's never had to leave it behind before.

My point of view is that it's my house and my rules, and I don't think it's an unreasonable rule to not want a gun in my home. I put my foot down the first time it happened because it was a serious matter and not like he brought the wrong snacks or something. Jim keeps texting me going back and forth between saying "lose my number" and sending me links to propaganda supporting his viewpoint.
"""

I think the author is not in the wrong, but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the author of the situation is in the wrong. The scenario is about someone who asked a group member, Jim, not to bring his concealed gun to their private game nights at their home. Jim didn't comply, and the author kicked him out of the group. The question is whether the author did the right thing.

First, I need to consider the legal and ethical aspects. In the U.S., concealed carry laws vary by state and local ordinances. If the author's state allows concealed carry, then Jim might have a legal right to carry his gun in public places. However, private property is different. The author is hosting the game at their home, which is private property. Generally, the owner can set rules for their property, including prohibiting weapons. So legally, the author has the right to ask Jim to leave his gun in the car or not come at all if he refuses.

Ethically, the author is anti-gun but didn't make the rule public before, which might be a point. They mentioned it privately to Jim. However, the author made it clear that guns weren't allowed in their house, and Jim didn't follow through. The author's main concern is safety and personal comfort in their own home. People have the right to feel safe in their own space. The author didn't force Jim to leave the group permanently until after the breach of the rule, which seems reasonable.

The other group members' reactions are mixed. Some agree, others think it was harsh. But the author's stance is about their own home. Jim's response was to quit, which he chose. The author didn't physically kick him out, just asked him not to come if he couldn't comply. The ongoing communication from Jim (texting, sending propaganda) might indicate he's not taking it well, but the author's actions were within their rights.

So, putting it all together, the author isn't in the wrong. They set a boundary for their home, and Jim didn't adhere, leading to his departure. The answer should be B.
